utterances: So, what do you do?
I am a social studies teacher in Arlington, Virginia.
And I live in Springfield, Virginia.
Okay, I don't want to be too nosy about this - but what do you make?
I make about $45,000 a year.
Okay, $45,000, so you're above the median income of about $35,000.
Right.
But still, are you making less than your dad?
Definitely.
Definitely.

And part, you know, part of that is what he did, which is he was a mortgage banker, but also, you know, part of it is what I do, and what I do is, you know, it's more than the median but living in northern Virginia, you have to also realize the cost of living here is really, really high, so...
Right.
So did you think that you would be making less than your dad at the same age?
You know, I guess you don't really think about it.
I mean, when my dad was 30, he was married, he had three kids, you know, and he was working hard as the sole earner, but earning, you know, a very good living.
And I'm 30 and I guess things have changed a lot.
I am married but I don't have kids and, you know, it's just my wife and I, we're both working, so it's a kind of different situation.
I'm not surprised that I earn less than him because of what I do.

But I think many people in America, considering how much work they put into their profession, are probably surprised that they do earn less than their fathers because they might do, you know, similar jobs, and especially with the changing demographics and with the changing professions in America, I'm sure a lot of people are surprised.
Well, and what about buying power?
Did your dad have his own house?
Yeah, definitely, he had his own house.
Do you?
My wife and I do have our own place, but it's a very different house.
It's a small townhouse and the only way that I was able to buy it is that I did get some help.
And I know most 30-somethings aren't getting that kind of support.
What about your friends?
Do you see the same thing with your friends and their dad?
Most of my friends, you know, I guess it's a different subject.
Most of my friends aren't married.
Most of my friends don't own a house.
Most of my friends are going from, you know, kind of paycheck-to-paycheck, trying to get by.
And so things are very different than they were, you know, 20 and 30 years ago.

You know, one thing that - the guy I just spoke with, John Morton, talked about was why they studied men in their 30s, is because it's a pretty good indicator of what their future earnings would be in their lifetime.
Right.
So does that give you pause?
It gives me pause on where I live now and what my plans are.

You know, as an educator you know that the ceiling for what earn is not very high, and so you have to consider all things, and you have to consider your plans, and although I don't have kids right now, I know my wife and I, you know, one day very soon would like to have a family, and can I really afford for her to give up her paycheck?
And the answer is no.
So it's either, okay, we become, you know, dual income, no kids, you know, dinks, as they say, or we decide to move, which is probably what we're going to do.
I'd like to be able to retire one day, and I don't think that would ever happen if I lived here.
I think I'd work until I die.
Unfortunately, I think a lot of Americans are going to be in that situation with the state of Social Security and with lowering incomes compared to the cost of living.
I'm sure lots of 30-somethings have quite a bit of pause.
Tim Churchill, 30 years old.
Thanks for joining us.
Thank you.
This month marks 25 years since the first reported cases of HIV/AIDS among gay men in Los Angeles and New York.
Men up and down the Broadway just started dropping down from some mystery disease, the little disease with no name, the disease that we now all know as HIV/AIDS.
They just started dropping dead.
Sick today, dead tomorrow.
And the silence would set in, that deadly silence.
Shhhh!
Nobody wanted to talk about it, much less do anything about that disease, that - Shhhh!
- that gay disease.
For the five women and two men of this choir, this room is not just an unlikely rehearsal space - it's a sanctuary from their regular lives, says choir director Linda Evans.
Coolâ€¦
And the other side of it is that this flag went up in the '50s and '60s largely in defense of white supremacy and in opposition to civil rights.

So for South Carolina finally to recognize this is, really in the end, a hateful symbol more than it is a symbol of heritage, maybe opens the way - as that teacher said on the good piece from down there - to start talking about other, more substantive steps we can take.
Let's shift gears a little bit.
Bernie Sanders, the Vermont Senator and Democratic presidential candidate, is having a pretty good week.
He's been having some - he's actually been having some good weeks, right?
He's - big crowds at campaign events, a surge in support.
E.J., what's happening here?
I mean, do you think he has a real shot at the nomination?
I think he has a shot to win primaries.
I still don't think he has a shot to win the nomination.
He hasn't proven that yet.
But Bernie Sanders, I like to say is ""Mr.
Smith Goes To Washington,"" except it's a Vermont Socialist with a Brooklyn accent.
I mean, there is something deeply authentic about this.
What he has to say speaks to not only a large part of the Democratic Party, but a lot of other Americans who are frustrated with the establishment.
He attacks both the political and economic establishment.
Now, I think as the campaign goes on, people are going to ask, OK, do I want to send a message with Bernie or do I want to send them a president?
It was a slogan that Jimmy Carter used many years ago.
And Hillary Clinton is giving an economic speech on Monday.
It's a fairly sweeping speech, from the way her campaign is describing it, and I think it's going to cover quite a lot of the ground that Bernie has been covering on the campaign trail.
David, what do you think this Bernie-mentum, as one of our reporters put it, means for Hillary Clinton?
People love University of Chicago students who want to become president.
(LAUGHTER)
Is this your announcement at candidacy?
The Republicans could use another candidate.
Yeah, that's true - not enough.
No, this is not going anywhere.
Listen, he's going to do well among university towns, but they're simply aren't enough sociology professors to push him over the top.
And he's shown no record, or even in the polling, much of evidence that he can do particularly well among less affluent, less progressive, working-class Democrats.
He has shown very little sign that he could do pretty well among African-Americans or Latino.
And without those big groups, he'll max-out at the university towns.
Could I caveat that just a little bit - if I can sound like Al Haig?
The - Iowa and New Hampshire are two states where he could do very well.
In Iowa, Hillary Clinton got less than a third of the caucus-goers.
She came in third.
That population who goes to the caucus is very progressive.
And New Hampshire's next-door, and he's already closed the gap.
Having said that, I still can't see Bernie going all the way and defeating Hillary Clinton.
And quickly - you know, on Wednesday, Republican candidate Jeb Bush said that in order to grow the economy, to get to the 4 percent growth, people need to work longer hours.
Then his campaign later, you know, clarified and said he was actually referring to part-time workers and the underemployed.
David, how did you understand these comments - quickly?
It was not - what he said was perfectly normal.
It seems to me, from the context, he was completely talking about part-time workers, and it was blown way out of proportion.

But it's a dangerous thing that Hillary, I think, is going to use in her speech on Monday because he didn't talk about we need to raise wages for people so they don't work fewer hours - even though I agree with David, as he explained, he meant to talk about part-time workers who were there involuntarily.
E.J.
Dionne of The Washington Post and David Brooks of The New York Times, thank you very much.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Extremists with the self-proclaimed Islamic State, or ISIS, have captured a Jordanian pilot in northern Syria.
He was flying as part of the U.S.-led coalition against ISIS when his fighter jet went down near Rocca, an ISIS stronghold.
In a moment we'll talk with a reporter who has just seen the coalition's fight up close.
NPR's Alice Fordham begins our coverage, though, and reports that today's incident has shaken Jordan.
The first the world heard of the crash was on Twitter.
Several images appeared on accounts usually used by ISIS, showing bearded men in camouflage carrying a young man with a bloodied mouth out to a lake.
The extremists gleefully posted pictures of the wreckage of a jet and of a military ID identifying the man as Mouaz al Kassessbeh.
The extremists claim they shot down the plane, but the U.S.
military released a statement saying evidence clearly indicates that ISIS did not shoot down the aircraft and the U.S.
will support efforts to get the pilot back.
Jordanian state media confirmed that a plane crashed and a pilot was taken hostage.
Mr. Kassessbeh's father told Jordanian media the family had been contacted by the Air Force.
The pilot's brother, Jawad, gave an interview to an opposition Syrian radio station.
(SOUNDBITE OF RADIO INTERVIEW)
(Foreign language spoken).
